introduction.p: The physical effect of connecting capacitors in parallel is to increase the effective area available for charges to spread over. Therefore we expect the net capacitance to go up when we connect capacitors in parallel. In this section we will figure out a formula for the equivalent capacitance.

sidebyside.p:
Consider a circuit with two capacitors C_1 and C_2 in parallel as shown in . Since the voltage source maitains a constant voltage, the voltage across the two capacitors will be equal. But, they will be charged to different amounts, say Q_1 and Q_2, depending upon thie capacitance according to Q=CV formula. Therefore, we have
Q_1 = C_1\, V,\ \ \ Q_2 = C_2\, V

introduction.p:
Now, suppose we wanted to replace the two capacitors by one capacitor, what should be the capacitance of this equaivalent capacitor? We definitely want the equivalent capacitor to store same total amount of charge.
Q_\text{on equivalent} = Q_1 + Q_2.
Now, it will have the same voltage V across it. This gives the following requirement for the capacitance C_\text{parallel} of the equivalent capacitor.
V = \frac{Q_1 + Q_2}{C_\text{parallel}}
Replacing Q_1 by C_1V and Q_2 by C_2V, yields the following for the equivalent capacitance.
C_\text{parallel} = C_1 + C_2.
This generalizes easily to the case of N capacitors in parallel.
C_\text{parallel} = C_1 + C_2+\cdots + C_N.
If you have widely different magnitude capacitances, it will be the capacitor that has the largest capacitance that will dominate the overall capacitance of the group. In some situations, it may be possible to ignore the capacitors with lower capacitances when in parallel to a capacitor with much higher capacitance as we will see in the following example.

exercise.title: Numerical Example of Capacitors in Parallel

statement.p: Evaluate the equivalent capacitance of the following capacitors connected in parallel. (a) C_1 = 1 \ \mu\text{F} , and C_2 = 1\ \mu\text{F}, (b) C_1 = 1\ \mu\text{F}, and C_2 = 1000\ \mu\text{F}, and (c) C_1 = 1 \ \mu\text{F}, and C_2 = 10^6\ \mu\text{F}.
